x.name: LE
y.name: M1
notes: Child mortality (0-14) vs life expectancy. Extended to LE=90 with lower rates for Canada. At LE=80+ (Canada's range), M1 is very low (~0.06%). Based on Statistics Canada vital statistics.

x.name: LE
y.name: M2
notes: Working-age mortality (15-44) vs LE. Extended to LE=90. At LE=82 (Canada), M2~0.05%. Based on Canadian actuarial tables.

x.name: LE
y.name: M3
notes: Older working-age mortality (45-64) vs LE. Extended to LE=90. At LE=82 (Canada), M3~0.6%. Based on Canadian actuarial tables.

x.name: LE
y.name: M4
notes: Elderly mortality (65+) vs LE. Extended to LE=90. At LE=82 (Canada), M4~4%. Reflects Canadian elderly care and healthcare system.

x.name: FPC/SFPC
y.name: LMF
notes: Life expectancy multiplier from food. Extended x-range for Canada where FPC/SFPC is typically 2.0-2.5 (food surplus nation). Multiplier saturates above ratio of 2.5.

x.name: SOPC
y.name: HSAPC
notes: CRITICAL RESCALING: Health services allocation per capita vs service output per capita. Original World3 x-range was 0-2000 (global developing world). Canada SOPC is 4000-10000. Canada spends ~$7,000 CAD per capita on health (universal system). Values reflect Canadian healthcare spending trajectory.

x.name: EHSPC
y.name: LMHS1
notes: RESCALED: Life expectancy multiplier from health services (before policy change). Extended x-range for Canadian healthcare spending levels (EHSPC 1000-2500). Diminishing returns at high spending levels reflect efficiency limits of healthcare.

x.name: EHSPC
y.name: LMHS2
notes: RESCALED: Life expectancy multiplier from health services (after policy change). Extended x-range for Canada. Saturates at 2.0 for high EHSPC.

x.name: POP
y.name: FPU
notes: CRITICAL RESCALING: Fraction of population urban vs total population. Original used 0-16B (global). Canada is 20-50M range with ~81% urban. Canada has been consistently 76-82% urban since 1971. Values based on Statistics Canada urban population data.

x.name: IOPC
y.name: CMI
notes: CRITICAL RESCALING: Crowding multiplier from industrialization vs industrial output per capita. Original x-range was 0-1600 (developing world). Canada IOPC is 20000-50000 (2015 USD). At high income, crowding effect is minimal or slightly positive (suburbanization).

x.name: PPOLX
y.name: LMP
notes: RESCALED: Life expectancy multiplier from pollution. Canada PPOLX ranges 1.0-2.0 (very low). Original table went to 100 (global worst-case). Canada has strict environmental regulations; pollution barely affects life expectancy.

x.name: LE
y.name: FM
notes: Fecundity multiplier vs life expectancy. Extended to LE=90. Biological relationship, mostly universal. At LE=82, FM~1.1 (near maximum biological fecundity).

x.name: PLE
y.name: CMPLE
notes: Compensatory multiplier from perceived life expectancy. Extended to PLE=90. At high LE (Canada range 73-82), people have fewer compensatory children. Value <1 at PLE=90 reflects very low fertility in high-LE nations.

x.name: DIOPC
y.name: SFSN
notes: CRITICAL RESCALING: Social family size norm vs delayed IOPC. Original x-range 0-800 (developing world). Canada DIOPC is 20000-50000 (2015 USD). At Canadian income levels, desired family size is very small (~1.3-1.6 children). Values reflect Canadian TFR trends.

x.name: FIE
y.name: FRSN
notes: Family response to social norm vs family income expectation. This is a behavioral response that doesn't need rescaling - FIE is already a ratio.

x.name: FCFPC
y.name: FCE_TOCLIP
notes: Family completion effectiveness. Ratio-based, no rescaling needed.

x.name: NFC
y.name: FSAFC
notes: Family size attribution from family compensation. Ratio-based, no rescaling needed.

x.name: LE
y.name: LEI
notes: Life expectancy index. Extended to LE=95 for future projections. Saturates at 1.0 for LE>=85.
